comment.text: Build updated, this fixes a critical security issue now.
Default & performance tests pass (KVM) for 5.13.4
@baptu: It hasn't reached your updates-testing mirror yet, it should be there in a few hours.
No issues with Ryzen 5900X, RX 6700XT. Performance test still took forever to complete, just like before :)
Good.

Works for me: desktop 16GB Intel i7-3770 CPU & laptop 8GB Intel i5-2520M CPU Lenovo T420 (the desktop ran the performance test in 10m14s, laptop 9m34s -- it's extremely rare that the laptop is faster, normally the laptop takes 10 times longer!!!) - all using the Mate Desktop Environment
>>>First time ever that 2 consecutive tests of a new kernel by have had the laptop faster than the desktop -- as far as I can remember! <<<

Noticed from a comment above that this had a AMD fix... it appears that this fix may have broken other things with AMD.  I'm using:
CPU: AMD A10-8700P Radeon R6 4C+6G (4) @ 1.800GHz 
GPU: AMD ATI Radeon R5/R6/R7 Graphics
@mattf Thanks for the update.  I tested with amdgpu.dc=0 and it circumvents the issue.  I closed 1984686 as a duplicate of your ticket:  1981039.  @jforbes, thanks for the update!

I am running a DELL G15se G5505 model and with the updated 5.13.4 kernel has issues booting.   If I run the older 5.12.x releases then there is no issue.

The issue resides in booting the kernel and it stops with 

fb0: switching to amdgpudrmfb from EFI GPU

It appears the console stops displaying commands but I am able to CTRL-ALT-F4 and use CTRL+ALT+DEL to restart and pick the older 5.12.x kernel from the grub boot menu.

I have logged in with Bugzilla via ticket:

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1985598

5.12.17 does not exhibit these issues.

Camera feed from Camlink keeps freezing in Zoom, not sure if this is related to this fix or it's something else in this kernel: https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/commit/?id=4c6e0976295add7f0ed94d276c04a3d6f1ea8f83

5.13.4 still has the black screen problem when starting Plasma and GNOME on Wayland involving the amdgpu driver that I reported for previous 5.13 kernels at https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1981039 I found that the first bad commit was in the 5.13 merge window using git bisect:
1f928f51593ca07e2b125ca862fcff687e9e498b drm/amdgpu: Use physical translation mode to access page table

This problem seems similar to that reported by @gbcox Adding amdgpu.dc=0 to the kernel command line allowed Plasma and GNOME on Wayland to run correctly. The default regression tests passed.

bugs.title: CVE-2021-33909 kernel: size_t-to-int conversion vulnerability in the filesystem layer

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2021-33909 kernel: size_t-to-int conversion vulnerability in the filesystem layer

long_desc.thetext:
An out-of-bounds write flaw was found in the seq_file in Filesystem layer, where a local attacker with a user privilege could gain access to out-of-bound memory leading to a system crash or a leak of internal kernel information. The issue results from not validating the size_t-to-int conversion prior to performing operations. The highest threat from this vulnerability is to data integrity, confidentiality and system availability.

While creating, mounting, and deleting a deep directory structure whose total path length exceeds 1GB, an unprivileged local attacker can write the 10-byte string "//deleted" to an offset of exactly -2GB-10B below the beginning of a vmalloc()ated kernel buffer.

References:
https://www.openwall.com/lists/oss-security/2021/07/20/1
https://www.qualys.com/2021/07/20/cve-2021-33909/sequoia-local-privilege-escalation-linux.txt

Fix:
https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/commit/?id=8cae8cd89f05f6de223d63e6d15e31c8ba9cf53b

*shrug*
Just don't let the damn thing ask for vmalloc'ed buffer that large.
IOW, add to seq_buf_alloc() if (unlikely(size > MAX_RW_COUNT)) return NULL;
and be done with that.

5.13.4 still has the black screen problem when starting Plasma and GNOME on Wayland involving the amdgpu driver that I reported for previous 5.13 kernels at https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1981039 I found that the first bad commit was in the 5.13 merge window using git bisect:
1f928f51593ca07e2b125ca862fcff687e9e498b drm/amdgpu: Use physical translation mode to access page table

This problem seems similar to that reported by @gbcox Adding amdgpu.dc=0 to the kernel command line allowed Plasma and GNOME on Wayland to run correctly. The default regression tests passed.

bugs.title: CVE-2021-33909 kernel: size_t-to-int conversion vulnerability in the filesystem layer [fedora-all]

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2021-33909 kernel: size_t-to-int conversion vulnerability in the filesystem layer [fedora-all]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2021-33909 kernel: size_t-to-int conversion vulnerability in the filesystem layer

long_desc.thetext:
An out-of-bounds write flaw was found in the seq_file in Filesystem layer, where a local attacker with a user privilege could gain access to out-of-bound memory leading to a system crash or a leak of internal kernel information. The issue results from not validating the size_t-to-int conversion prior to performing operations. The highest threat from this vulnerability is to data integrity, confidentiality and system availability.

While creating, mounting, and deleting a deep directory structure whose total path length exceeds 1GB, an unprivileged local attacker can write the 10-byte string "//deleted" to an offset of exactly -2GB-10B below the beginning of a vmalloc()ated kernel buffer.

References:
https://www.openwall.com/lists/oss-security/2021/07/20/1
https://www.qualys.com/2021/07/20/cve-2021-33909/sequoia-local-privilege-escalation-linux.txt

Fix:
https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/commit/?id=8cae8cd89f05f6de223d63e6d15e31c8ba9cf53b

*shrug*
Just don't let the damn thing ask for vmalloc'ed buffer that large.
IOW, add to seq_buf_alloc() if (unlikely(size > MAX_RW_COUNT)) return NULL;
and be done with that.

comments.text:
I am running a DELL G15se G5505 model and with the updated 5.13.4 kernel has issues booting.   If I run the older 5.12.x releases then there is no issue.

The issue resides in booting the kernel and it stops with 

fb0: switching to amdgpudrmfb from EFI GPU

It appears the console stops displaying commands but I am able to CTRL-ALT-F4 and use CTRL+ALT+DEL to restart and pick the older 5.12.x kernel from the grub boot menu.

I have logged in with Bugzilla via ticket:

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1985598
